title: Debouncing

description.question: What is Debouncing?
description.answer: Debouncing is a programming technique that prevents a function from being called too frequently within a short time frame. It ensures that the function executes only after a specified delay when the event is no longer being triggered repeatedly.

description.question: Use Case:
description.answer:
• Used in search bars to prevent excessive API calls.
  • Improves performance by limiting repeated execution of costly operations.
  • Prevents unnecessary event handling in UI interactions.

description.question: How Does Debouncing Work?
description.answer: Debouncing works by setting a timer whenever an event is triggered. If the event occurs again before the timer expires, the previous timer is cleared, and a new one starts. The function executes only if no new events occur within the delay period.

description.question: Example:
description.answer:
• A user types in a search box â†’ A function triggers to fetch search results.
  • Without debouncing: The function runs on every keystroke, making too many API calls.
  • With debouncing: The function waits until the user stops typing for a certain period before making an API call.

description.question: Basic Steps:
description.answer:
• Wrap the function inside a debounce function.
  • Use setTimeout to delay execution.
  • Clear the previous timer when a new event occurs before the delay ends.
  • Execute the function only when the delay period completes without further triggers.
